content.div:
The Decemberists

We All Raise Our Voices to the Air (Live Songs 04.11-08.11)

(Capitol/EMI)

It's fitting that an early candidate for 2012's wordiest live-album title would come from the Decemberists, considering how much Colin Meloy has to say in his opulent lyrics and in concert. Since his barbed banter is a constant in the live show, it's wisely kept as a constant in this two-disc souvenir (although the bit about Keith Urban fans being at the wrong gig probably made more sense in context). The band itself is tremendously inconstant, which is not a criticism: there's enough room on stage for the dusty authenticity of "Down by the Water" and the vaudevillian melodrama of "The Mariner's Revenge Song." An occasional brass section and guest Sara Watkins' violin add colour to performances that are even more vigorous than their studio counterparts.

Rating: 4 out of 5

--Jordan Zivitz, Postmedia News

--

The Ting Tings

Sounds from Nowheresville

(Columbia)

Indie rock. Dance-punk. New wave. England's The Ting Tings seem dedicated to exploring enough precious sub-genres to transform every review into the tag cloud of an annoyingly hip music blog. But somehow, the duo mostly make it work, with energy and endlessly looped handclaps. The variety is impressive. Sometimes the Ting Tings sound like Portishead running their instruments through amplifiers instead of supercomputers. On other tracks, it's Blondie making fun of ska. "Guggenheim" has a Velvet Underground/Nico vibe without the weightiness. "One by One" sounds as if it should be the menu music of an early '90s Nintendo game. And "Give It Back" fires off bursts of controlled guitar energy. Still, there are a few too many ironic Ke$ha rap verses and forced bounciness for everything to really come together.

Rating: 3 out of 5

--Al Kratina, Postmedia News

--

Katie Melua

Secret Symphony

(Dramatico)

What's the minimum age required to be world-weary? Katie Melua has one of those old souls, a born Melua-ncholia in her neo-schmaltz. In some ways, that's remarkable. Already five albums in, she has a real handle on this swoony, sophisticated mid-Atlantic "standards" vibe. Here, the world "beat" touches on "Pictures" (they weren't exactly poundingly rhythmic) shift to strings. She's sad. She's also identifiably grown-up, which is a relief, with a lovely voice, a smart adult contempo with jazzoid touches poised beyond her years. But despite the creativity, there's something awfully easy about it; a little too Kahlua, you know? There is a fine line between soothing and somnambulant, between moody and MOR, and some way to go to becoming Leonard Cohen, assuming that's the goal.

Rating: 3.5 out of 5

--Mark Lepage, Postmedia News

--

Meat Loaf

Hell in a Handbasket

(Legacy/Sony)

You get the idea that Marvin Lee Aday was a large baby, one of those record-setters, who came storming out of the womb wailing at the devil. Or for a shrink. Sounds like he met one in "All of Me," the therapy anthem leading off Hell in an Umpteenth Title Use of Hell. Mock-operatic, he's on about some kind of Faustian bargain, and as ever, something about the Sturm makes you want to pull for him. Even in the semi-demented "The Giving Tree." Bolstered by these brontosauran themes, Mr. Loaf still sings every lyric as though sobbing and bleeding on the altar of St. Bombasticus. It's always odd to run into someone who never realized that rock wasn't here to absorb Broadway-style drama -- it was here to replace it. By the way, did we need another version of "California Dreamin'?"

Rating: 2.5 out of 5

--Mark Lepage, Postmedia News

link.Abstract: Someone should probably tell her she's starring in the Hunger Games, then.
link.title: Jennifer Lawrence Doesn't Want to Be as Famous as Kristen Stewart

link.Abstract: If we learned one thing from Liam Hemsworth's Details interview, it's that the dude is easily distracted by squirrels. Funny, we're easily distracted by Liam Hemsworth. But who's cuter?! We're pretty sure we know how the Hunger Games star will be voting, but we'll let you decide. For each slide, cast your vote!
link.title: Who's Cuter: Liam Hemsworth or a Squirrel?

link.Abstract: The young actor is doing everything these days -- including climbing palm trees between interviews.
link.title: Josh Hutcherson Says He Hungered for The Hunger Games

link.Abstract: Adele will play the BRIT Awards on Feb. 21, buoying hopes that the "Someone Like You" singer might also perform at the Grammy Awards Feb. 12.
